commit_list.message:
Updated identity check example to use correct method call when sending a ZMQ::Message

The correct method in the latest version of the `ffi-rzmq` gem used to send a message via a socket is `#sendmsg`.

See http://rdoc.info/gems/ffi-rzmq/ZMQ/CommonSocketBehavior#sendmsg-instance_method for more info.

commit_list.message:
Adding attributes specification support on simple queries (see `Arangoex.Simple`)

  NOTE: This slightly changes the optional parameter API used on
  `Arangoex.Simple` so that most of the functions in that module now
  take an arglist that looks like:

  `def fun(collection_name, attrs \\ [], opts \\ [])`

  `attrs` is intended for database query options and `opts` is
  intended for specifying options for the HTTP layer.

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  * Added documentation
  * Added tests
commit_list.repo_description: An elixir driver for ArangoDB.

commit_list.message:
Normalize message and enum names from lowercase so that they can be
correctly use Elixir's module/function naming rules.

  For example:

     `message msgHeader { ... }` will be built as `MsgHeader` in
      Elixir's module namespace. The same rules apply to `enum` types.

  Even though the protobuf style guide says that these names
  should be capitalized, they are many protobuf implementations that
  allow this (including the c++ implementation by google).

  * Moving normalization of module names before building macros

  * Fixing typo on pipeline

  * Prove that encoding works with lower-cased proto definitions
commit_list.repo_description: Protocol Buffers in Elixir made easy!

Raising KeyError if any items in representation set fail -- Fixes #14

    true in `HalClient::RepresentationSet#has_related?`

    instances were trying to be created

commit_list.message:
Fixes assumption of executing block on initialization of a model

  This was causing ActiveModel classes to not get hydrated.

  ActiveRecord automatically handles executing blocks on
  initialization of its models, but ActiveModel does not.

  Instead, we explicitly call the block on initialization to not rely
  on ActiveModel or ActiveRecord to do it for us.

commit_list.message:
Adding `extract_repr` and `extract_reprs` to HalInterpretation DSL

  These methods will allow the DSL user to work with a
  HalClient::Representation or HalClient::RepresentationSet for use on
  the model's associated property or for any coercion work that needs
  to be done. Please see README and method documentation for more
  details on usage and implementation.

commit_list.message:
Extending Runners API to include GET /runners call

  * The GET /runners call retrieves a list of all runners registered
    on the Gitlab CI instance.
Adding further documentation and corrections on builds and runners
Adding API documentation for Projects
Adding new line at end of git ignore file
Cleaning up environmental changes from development process

Fixed several specs after extending api for projects

  * Fixed several deprecation warnings

  * Removed webmock in favor of running integration tests against
    demo.gitlab.com
Added passing specs for remainder of projects API

Adding user access checking per project

  * Made :per_page and :page on Project.from_gitlab optional for API
    calls

  * Added call to retrieve Gitlab CI projects that are not only
    authorized, but "owned"

Adding Project manipulation support via API

  * The following actions are now supported:

    GET /projects/:id - returns information about a project
    GET /projects - returns list of all projects
    PUT /projects/:id - updates project information (see docs for more info)
    DELETE /projects/:id - removes a project
    POST /projects/:id/runners/:runner_id - links a project to a runner
    DELETE /projects/:id/runners/:runner_id - removes link between project and runner

Adding POST /projects (for creation) and several rspec unit stubs for
projects api
Adding specs for Project API end points
Implementing method for authentication via token

Extending Runners API to include GET /runners call

  * The GET /runners call retrieves a list of all runners registered
    on the Gitlab CI instance.

commit_list.message:
Fixing several items for 1.1.0 release

  * Added NDFD::DWML class to handle parsing of XML responses
  * Added Travis CI testing on 2.1.1
  * Explicitly changed to simplecov 0.7.1 because of outstanding bug (see https://github.com/colszowka/simplecov/issues/281)
  * Refreshed VCR cassettes
  * Removed GML api methods (the endpoints on the service don't work as expected)
  * Removed XSLT translation (it did not handle responses with multiple lat/longs) in favor of pure ruby parsing
  * Removed vendor folder (previous reference to noaa-dwml-to-json-xslt)
  * Updated documentation regarding GML methods

commit_list.repo_description: Use HAL APIs with ease

commit_list.message:
Adds templated link support when transcoding HAL documents and Maps

  Given the following:

```elixir
  defmodule MyTranscoder do
    use ExHal.Transcoder

    deflink "fillmein", param: :fillmein, templated: true
  end
```

  When you call `MyTranscoder.decode!(doc)` on a HAL document that looks like
  this:

```json
  {
    "_links": {
       "fillmein": { "href": "http://example.com/resource{?data}", "templated": true}
    }
  }
```

  Then you will still have the templated link in it's original form in
  the decoded struct like so:

```elixir
  %{fillmein: "http://example.com/resource{?data}"}
```

  =============================================================================

  NOTE: This provides a clear distinction of making links templated or
  not whereas before `templated` was always set to `false` by the
  encoder/decoder.
commit_list.repo_description: Use HAL APIs with ease

commit_list.repo_description: Use HAL APIs with ease

commit_list.message: Adding `defextractlink` functionality
commit_list.repo_description: Use HAL APIs with ease

commit_list.message:
Adding ExHal.Interpreter module to define mappers in applications

```elixir
defmodule MyInterpreter do
  use ExHal.Intepreter

  defextract :first_name
  defextract :last_name
end
```

This would create a `to_params/1` function on `MyInterpreter` that
would be called with an ExHal.Document:

```elixir
  iex(1)> MyInterpreter.to_params(doc)
  => %{first_name: ..., last_name: ...}
```

If the ExHal.Document does not have a property , it will default that
particular parameter to `nil`

commit_list.message:
Adding Hal Document serialization into a json-like shape

  NOTE: Actual encoding is left up to the user. For example,
  you will want to do something like this to make real JSON:

     ExHal.Collection.to_json_hash([ex_hal_doc]) |> Poison.encode!

  or

     ExHal.Document.to_json_hash(ex_hal_doc) |> Poison.encode!

  or

     ExHal.Link.to_json_hash(ex_hal_link) |> Poison.encode!

commit_list.repo_description: Use HAL APIs with ease

commit_list.message:
Allows setting headers when following links and making HTTP requests
(right now just POST)

CHANGES

  * Updated the `ExHal.Document` struct to support a new key,
    `headers`.  This gets set when you parse a response from following
    a link or making a post.  By default, this value is just an empty
    map.  In the case you are manually parsing hal documents from
    strings, the default value will be set in `headers`.  Old APIs
    still work.

  * Removed the `ExHal.Document.listify` function in favor of using
    `List.wrap`

  * Added excoveralls as a test dependency to figure out the test
    coverage percentages.

EXTRA NOTES

  * As part of this addition, I removed all instances of `Dict` in
    favor of using `Map` and, in one case, Keyword (for HTTPoision's
    API). The reason for this is because `Dict` is currently
    soft-deprecated and will be removed in future releases of Elixir.

  * I also wasn't able to verify that the headers are being sent
    through VCR, but I did test the whole path manually and it does work.

    definitions to fail.  Wrapping those in blocks now for delayed
    execution.

commit_list.repo_description: Rails 3 Engine Blog Software

commit_list.message:
Integration testing with Steak instead of Cucumber

I've decided that it is in the best interest of this project and its maintainers
to remove Cucumber's added abstraction level for integration testing and replace
it with something that feels more like literal Ruby.

I have struggled with this decision to make this change because I feel very
comfortable writing cucumber features/steps, but I understand that others don't.

Hopefully, this change will do the following:

1. Make it easier to read, write and search the code by using standard ruby APIs
2. Remove an abstraction that doesn't offer any speed improvements
3. Use capybara's API interface directly for finely grained control over our tests
3. Add to general happiness and welfare to the world around us

I came to this conclusion after reading several recent articles on current
attitudes toward Cucumber and its place in the business world.

Since this project is run solely by programmers, it really offers the development
team nothing because we are specifying our own requirements, not handing them to
middle-management for review and acceptance.

So, henceforth, from this day forward, I now declare this project Cucumber-free.
